headline: US Detains Two Men Accused of Smuggling Nvidia AI Gear to China
summary: A third, the owner of a Houston company, has already pleaded guilty.  The department alleges the men operated a smuggling network that spanned the Houston business, run by Alan Hao Hsu, and several warehouses across the US, which replaced Nvidia labels from H100 and H200 AI chips with the fictional “Sandkyan” brand before shipping them.  Fanyue Gong, a Chinese citizen residing in Brooklyn, New York, and Benlin Yuan, a Canadian from Ontario, are alleged to have conspired with employees of a Hong Kong-based logistics company and a China-based AI technology company to circumvent US export controls.

content.title: US Detains Two Men Accused of Smuggling Nvidia AI Gear to China
content.summary: A third, the owner of a Houston company, has already pleaded guilty.  The department alleges the men operated a smuggling network that spanned the Houston business, run by Alan Hao Hsu, and several warehouses across the US, which replaced Nvidia labels from H100 and H200 AI chips with the fictional “Sandkyan” brand before shipping them.  Fanyue Gong, a Chinese citizen residing in Brooklyn, New York, and Benlin Yuan, a Canadian from Ontario, are alleged to have conspired with employees of a Hong Kong-based logistics company and a China-based AI technology company to circumvent US export controls.

headline: US to allow Nvidia H200 chip shipments to China, Trump says
summary:
STORY: President Donald Trump on Monday said Nvidia will be allowed to sell its H200 artificial intelligence chips to China—but at a price.

The U.S. government will collect a 25% fee for each chip exported, higher than the 15% floated in August. 

A White House official says it will be collected as an import tax from Taiwan, where the chips are made, before they undergo U.S. security checks and head to China.

Nvidia shares jumped after Trump’s announcement on Truth Social — up 2% after hours, following a 3% rise earlier on reports of the deal.

Trump said he informed Chinese President Xi Jinping about the decision, and Xi responded positively, according to the post.

Trump added that the U.S. Commerce Department is finalizing details of the deal and the same approach would apply to other AI chip firms such as AMD and Intel.

The move appears to settle debate over whether American chipmakers should sell to China or hold back to protect U.S. dominance in AI. 

However, critics in Washington say shipping high-end AI chips to China risks supercharging its military.

Democratic senators criticized the decision, calling it a major economic and national security failure.

Experts say Nvidia's H200 is nearly six times more powerful than the H20, which is the most advanced chip currently allowed for export to China. 

But it’s still slower than Nvidia’s Blackwell chips, which U.S. firms use for AI training and deployment.

content.title: US to allow Nvidia H200 chip shipments to China, Trump says
content.summary:
STORY: President Donald Trump on Monday said Nvidia will be allowed to sell its H200 artificial intelligence chips to China—but at a price.

The U.S. government will collect a 25% fee for each chip exported, higher than the 15% floated in August. 

A White House official says it will be collected as an import tax from Taiwan, where the chips are made, before they undergo U.S. security checks and head to China.

Nvidia shares jumped after Trump’s announcement on Truth Social — up 2% after hours, following a 3% rise earlier on reports of the deal.

Trump said he informed Chinese President Xi Jinping about the decision, and Xi responded positively, according to the post.

Trump added that the U.S. Commerce Department is finalizing details of the deal and the same approach would apply to other AI chip firms such as AMD and Intel.

The move appears to settle debate over whether American chipmakers should sell to China or hold back to protect U.S. dominance in AI. 

However, critics in Washington say shipping high-end AI chips to China risks supercharging its military.

Democratic senators criticized the decision, calling it a major economic and national security failure.

Experts say Nvidia's H200 is nearly six times more powerful than the H20, which is the most advanced chip currently allowed for export to China. 

But it’s still slower than Nvidia’s Blackwell chips, which U.S. firms use for AI training and deployment.

headline: Asian shares slip after Wall Street pulls back from its record heights
summary: Asian shares mostly fell Tuesday after U.S. stocks pulled away from their record heights, while U.S. futures edged higher.  Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index was the main outlier, gaining 0.2% to 50,691.39.  The S&P/ASX 200 in Australia gave up 0.2% to 8,607.80 after the Reserve Bank opted to keep its cash rate unchanged at 3.6%.

content.title: Asian shares slip after Wall Street pulls back from its record heights
content.summary: Asian shares mostly fell Tuesday after U.S. stocks pulled away from their record heights, while U.S. futures edged higher.  Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index was the main outlier, gaining 0.2% to 50,691.39.  The S&P/ASX 200 in Australia gave up 0.2% to 8,607.80 after the Reserve Bank opted to keep its cash rate unchanged at 3.6%.

headline: Tech Weekly: Nvidia gets China nod, eye-catching robots
summary:
STORY: Nvidia gets a Chinese bonus but with a price... to eye-catching robots...

This is Tech Weekly.

:: Tech Weekly

Nvidia can sell its second-best AI chips to China, but with a price.

U.S. President Donald Trump confirmed Washington will allow the sale of H200 processors but collect a 25% fee on such sales.

It's higher than the 15% levy suggested in August.

The White House said it will be collected as an import tax from Taiwan, where the chips are made, before they undergo U.S. security checks and head to China.

Australia is on course to ban under 16s from using social media.

It would make it the first country to bring in a minimum age for social media use.

And could lead to fines of around $33 million if 10 of the biggest platforms, including Meta and TikTok, don't follow along.

Major tech firms and free speech advocates have criticized the move, but parents and child advocates have praised it. 

China's LandSpace rocket failed to complete its reusable rocket test.

The firm had hoped to become the third company after SpaceX and Blue Origin to successfully test a reusable spacecraft.

State media said the Zhuque-3 rocket couldn't complete a controlled landing following an initial launch.

The latest advances in robotic technology were on show in Japan at the International Robot Exhibition.

Some were able to show their rescue capabilities during disasters,

While others danced and served up drinks.

Some like Kawasaki Corporation's Kaleido 9 robot could one day be used in disaster areas where human access is difficult.

And India is reviewing a proposal about greater phone-location surveillance.

That's according to documents, emails and five sources.

The pitch is from the telecom industry to force smartphone firms to enable satellite location tracking.

Tech majors, including Apple, Google and Samsung, have all opposed the move due to privacy concerns.

content.title: Tech Weekly: Nvidia gets China nod, eye-catching robots
content.summary:
STORY: Nvidia gets a Chinese bonus but with a price... to eye-catching robots...

This is Tech Weekly.

:: Tech Weekly

Nvidia can sell its second-best AI chips to China, but with a price.

U.S. President Donald Trump confirmed Washington will allow the sale of H200 processors but collect a 25% fee on such sales.

It's higher than the 15% levy suggested in August.

The White House said it will be collected as an import tax from Taiwan, where the chips are made, before they undergo U.S. security checks and head to China.

Australia is on course to ban under 16s from using social media.

It would make it the first country to bring in a minimum age for social media use.

And could lead to fines of around $33 million if 10 of the biggest platforms, including Meta and TikTok, don't follow along.

Major tech firms and free speech advocates have criticized the move, but parents and child advocates have praised it. 

China's LandSpace rocket failed to complete its reusable rocket test.

The firm had hoped to become the third company after SpaceX and Blue Origin to successfully test a reusable spacecraft.

State media said the Zhuque-3 rocket couldn't complete a controlled landing following an initial launch.

The latest advances in robotic technology were on show in Japan at the International Robot Exhibition.

Some were able to show their rescue capabilities during disasters,

While others danced and served up drinks.

Some like Kawasaki Corporation's Kaleido 9 robot could one day be used in disaster areas where human access is difficult.

And India is reviewing a proposal about greater phone-location surveillance.

That's according to documents, emails and five sources.

The pitch is from the telecom industry to force smartphone firms to enable satellite location tracking.

Tech majors, including Apple, Google and Samsung, have all opposed the move due to privacy concerns.

headline: Apple’s Slow AI Pace Becomes a Strength as Market Grows Weary of Spending
summary: Through the first six months of 2025, Apple was the second-worst performer among the Magnificent Seven tech giants, as its shares tumbled 18% through the end of June.  “It is remarkable how they have kept their heads and are in control of spending, when all of their peers have gone the other direction,” said John Barr, portfolio manager of the Needham Aggressive Growth Fund, which owns Apple shares.

content.title: Apple’s Slow AI Pace Becomes a Strength as Market Grows Weary of Spending

headline: The Global Market for Low Power/High Efficiency AI Semiconductors 2026-2036
summary: The low power/high efficiency AI semiconductor market is rapidly evolving, driven by demand for devices achieving power efficiency exceeding 10 TFLOPS/W. Spanning neuromorphic and in-memory computing, edge AI processors, and specialized neural units, this market caters to diverse applications from IoT to automotive systems, addressing critical energy efficiency needs. Anticipated to grow significantly through 2036, key players include NVIDIA, Intel, Qualcomm, and numerous startups. Regional comp
